Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2010 07:28PM Medigal wrote: Frankie, I am so sorry the waiting is making you crazy.  This damnable disease makes most of us crazy!  I can never understand how our Oncs can be so thoughtless not to understand the fears we live with.  My Onc I think would put me in a cage if he could when he has to do tests.  I just keep calling the office and telling them my nerves can't take the wait and I NEED to know the results before they leave that day!  What I have learned from experience is that it seems to be true that "bad news travels fast".  If it is bad they want to contact you, in my opinion, so they can set up the next step or test.  If it isn't bad, they seem to have this crappy attitude that they have all their other patients to take care of and it is no big deal if they make us wait a few days before calling.  I usually call the place where I had the test to see if they sent results to my Onc and if they say "yes" and he should have them, I call his office and insist on getting the results. So he thinks I am a nutcase.  Who cares!!  He is not the one who has to live with my fears.  I also don't think I would still be surviving if a "caring" doc several years ago had not given me a tranquilizer RX and taught me how to take it without getting addicted to it.  If you don't get your answer soon, you might want to do what I do.  It amazes me how these doctors can be so good at their professions yet so terrible when it comes to understanding the feelings of their patients. You have to confront them and let them know it is too upsetting for you when you have to wait on results.  Being this upset is also not good if you have blood pressure problems.  Best of luck to you and many hugs!
Posts.Title: I'am going CRAZY!!! Frankie_ FireKracker

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2010 07:19PM Medigal wrote: This is odd, in my opinion.  Usually if the mammo is questionable they send you for an ultrasound to make sure but in your case this seems to change the usual.  However, I was told that a mammo can show certain lumps and an ultrasound other types.  Since your have had bc in your family, your doctor may want to do a needle biopsy to try to find the suspicious lumps and decide what they are. Not too long ago they had to do that to me because they were uncertain of what they were seeing on the films and it turned out to be just benign calcifications.  Maybe it will be the same for you.Let's hope so!
Posts.Title: Positive Mammo but negative ultra sound? bestauntie bestauntie

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2010 11:31AM Medigal wrote: notsure:  The main reason I always have all and any mammos done at the same facility even if my insurance wants me to go to a cheaper one is because they have all the films and can compare them to each other.  Anytime I would go to a new place, they would want extra mammos due to any blur they saw which "could" be something.  Maybe they saw a spot on yours that they don't really know what it is and will insist on another film to see if it shows up again.  It's not so much about their making extra money on you as their making a wrong decision about something and you will be  very upset if they do.  The 2nd opinion doc can't be sure the first doc was correct unless he makes his own films and has his own people check them out, in my opinion. It is aggravating for you but if you did not have a concern, I don't think you would be wanting a 2nd opinion.  Call them and try to see if they can reschedule you for a time and day you can make it.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2010 09:55AM Medigal wrote: Whoa!!  What's going on here??  How could you be released?  I thought this was a lifetime marriage with our Oncs.  I was diagnosed 8/2003 and have been taking Arimidex since 1/2004.  This August I would have been diagnosed with bc for 7 years and this January 2011 on Arimidex 7 years!  My Onc wants me to continue on the Arimidex so does that mean no divorce for me until who knows when?  I see my Onc two times a year and this May's appt. I think I am going to ask him how long this nightmare has to continue.  However, I don't believe that anyone is really a cancer survivor once it gets in their bodies.  But it does take years before a tumor can be felt or found on the mammo so why can't we be discharged and just do our mammos yearly??  Just wondering how this works for the majority of people who got bc.  Thanks.

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2010 06:14AM Medigal wrote: Sherri:  It dawned on me that if I convinced my Onc to discharge me, I would have no one to check my breasts for possible lumps every 6 months.  I was told I don't need pap smears any longer since I had a partial hyster many years ago and the ovary that was left has shriveled up to a prune!  So I don't have any reason at this point to see a gyn regularly.  I don't trust checking myself so I guess it is better to keep going back regularly to him and he also sets up my annual mammos and bone density tests (for Arimidex SEs).   Sooooo I'll let him decide when it's time to divorce me.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2012 07:09AM - edited Feb 25, 2012 07:10AM by Medigal Quite a few years ago, I injured my shoulders and ended up with severe rotator cuff pain.  I went to several orthopedic doctors and two wanted to do surgery.  However, when I got to the third surgeon, he said I had two options.  Have surgery done and end up with even more severe pain from the surgery scar tissue for the rest of my life or take 3 years to "wait it out and let it heal on it's own with shoulder exercises he would give me".  Now 3 years seemed like a nightmare at the time but I have gone longer in my life to try to survive injuries to my body.  He felt he could not recommend shoulder surgery due to the additional problems it brings in this area.  Well, I did the exercises and I made sure and still do that I never pick up or carry any thing which feels too heavy and his timeline was on target.  It did take the three years  but one day I realized the intense pain was gone.  I still get pain to this day if I overdue but nothing like I suffered back then. This is an important decision for someone to make and what was right for me may not be right for you.  I would be sure to get a second opinion before I opted for surgery.  Now my problem was many years ago and maybe they have found a way to make shoulder surgery less of a problem.  Just question the surgeon about resulting scar tissue pain and other possible complications from any surgery if you opt for it, imo.
Posts.Title: Alternate ways to deal with rotator cuff pain? Ysa Ysa

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 02:09PM - edited Feb 16, 2011 02:11PM by Medigal A cure for cancer is being able to live long enough to die of something else.  Basically that is what my Onc told me when I asked him if I would survive it.  I worked for years raising money for another chronic disease to help my DD and it's been over 30 years and I wonder where the thousands of dollars I raised with so many others went to.  I finally gave the fundraising up when I found out so much was being wasted!  My DD didn't want me to continue since she feels no one really cares about curing her or the millions of others with her disease.  They make such money on these diseases that it makes one wonder if it can possibly be true that our people who are involved in "curing" diseases make more from the disease than from a cure!  I "hope" for a cure for everything but don't think I will see it in my lifetime.  The best they can do is find other treatments to help us survive as long as possible.  I am sorry to be such a pessimist but not all dreams come true.  However, I do "hope" for a cure for cancer and so many of the other debilitating diseases mankind suffers from.
Posts.Title: Do you have HOPE or CONFIDENCE in a cure? BaseballFan sandilee

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 06:13PM Medigal wrote: Granny:  You hit the nail on the head!   I can't believe with the knowledge they have found for other things, they can't find a way to cure cancer and diabetes.  When one vial of insulin costs $100.00 do we really think they want to cure such a money making disease?  I think it is the same with bc.  They talk the talk but they sure don't "walk the walk" when it comes to finding a cure!  They fill us full of drugs, radiation, chemo, and they still can't tell us 100% that we are cancer free!  Like I said in an earlier post, the only cure I see for bc is dying of something else!  And that's the way it was put to me when I asked my medical professional about whether I would ever be totally cured.   Keep up the fight Granny!  Our survival is in our determination to survive!
Posts.Title: Do you have HOPE or CONFIDENCE in a cure? BaseballFan sandilee

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 06:46PM Medigal wrote: Granny:  Do you realize what a miracle it is that your niece has survived 42 years with diabetes?? I thought my DD was so fortunate to have made it 32 years.  She got it at 8 years old.  No one but their loved ones know what a frightening road that is when these children get it so young.  Yet after all these years where are the stemcell transplants that were supposed to cure our kids??  I guess the same place as the "cure" for cancer!  Sorry for being so hostile about this subject but we were given "hope" over 30 years ago for a diabetes cure and now no mention.  So am I really supposed to think they are going to "cure" cancer?  Forgive me if I have lost faith in the medical establishment and the pharmaceutical industry.  So sorry about your niece, Granny.  Hope she didn't get any of the horrible diabetic complications which comes after years of struggling with that disease.  I will remember her in my prayers as well as you and all of us trying to survive our curse.
Posts.Title: Do you have HOPE or CONFIDENCE in a cure? BaseballFan sandilee

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 10:39PM Medigal wrote: Becky what has happened to your body with bc is similar to what happens to people who have diabetes for many years and got it as children.  By the time they so come up with the so called "cure" (if they ever do!) the bodies of the people will have been basically destroyed by what they have had to incur with the disease or taken to survive the disease.  I know this is a bc support group but diabetes has many similarities to cancer, IMO, and I was just making a point about their similarities with the "hope for a cure" for both.  I hope you continue to have the strength and courage to cope with what trying to survive bc has done to your body.  It is hard for me to accept that we are in 2011 and people like yourself still have no protection from the destruction this damnable disease can do to one's internal organs and body as a whole.  I do hope your scans will not show more damage. Courage be with you.
Posts.Title: Do you have HOPE or CONFIDENCE in a cure? BaseballFan sandilee

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 05:44PM Medigal wrote: Lowrider:  What you posted makes a lot of sense.  We think in terms of a "cure" but in a way a drug like the Arimidex, if it is truly keeping me cancer free for over 7 years, has been a type of "cure" for me.  If Arimidex or Tamoxifen had never been discovered, I wonder where many of us with ER+ bc would be today.  However, the scary part is having to end our journey with it since it is supposed to be for only 5 years.  My Onc keeps stretching my time with it out as long as my bones hold up but one has to wonder how safe this is.  One also has to wonder where one would be if not on Arimidex. Kind of scary.

They allowed that.  I see so many doctors for other problems, I just didn't want to add another one to it.  I think if my Onc felt it was that important he would insist I keep up with the BS.

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2010 07:17PM - edited Sep 25, 2010 07:18PM by Medigal I think Chrissyb gave as good an answer as can be found at this time.  However, what you have to also think about is did the women who had better stages and grades in the beginning with no negative nodes maybe refused to take Chemo and Rads because they felt they were safer?  From what I have learned, "no" one is safe no matter how good their diagnosis seems to be at the time. I was once informed by a very "bright" man that after all of his research on bc even women who went the entire 9 yards (bi-lateral Masts etc.) could not positively be protected because of that "one" evil, dangerous, rogue cell which may be roaming in the body and return at some time (no one knows when) and bring the "curse" back again.  I have always wondered why my surgeon refused to do as I requested and remove the entire right breast and anything else he needed to to save my life.  Maybe he realized that doing that was not going to "probably" protect me as well as just doing the lumpectomy and removing the 27 nodes of which one was positive.  He then hit me with weeks of Chemo and Radiation.  But I was willing to do the Chemo and Rads and then start the Arimidex.  I read about women who let their fear take control of them and they refuse to follow up with the treatments they need.  Too bad we don't have the statistics for all of these different sets of women and what their survival rates were and what their diagnosis, treatments etc. were and if they did or did not do the treatment.   When and "if" they ever find the right way to send something through our bodies which will target "every" cancer cell possibly roaming in our bodies, then they will have cured cancer!  The concern is how potent the treatment would have to be to do this and what would it do to the rest of our insides or outsides.   Just wondering.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2011 12:30PM Medigal wrote: Caren:  I have no idea what dxs fall into certain categories.  I was very shocked when my Onc blew my mine by his info.  Maybe they have a manual which gives them this info.  I don't think he would just make it up to upset me.  Next time I see him, I just may ask him if that info is available to patients on the internet and where I can find it.  I know I was trying to find an excuse to quit Arimidex that day after being on it for almost 8 years and he was giving me his reason for why he felt I needed the extra help.  I am ER+, PR+, Herp-2 neu positive.  When I was diagnosed, they would not give Herceptin to anyone unless they were Stage IV so I have never gotten the drug. Sorry I can't be of more help.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2010 01:11PM Medigal wrote: I have always lived with pain of one type or another but unfortunately due to a sensitive stomach cannot endure anything but 6 tylenols a day.  But I will give you a laugh.  One time some years ago when I was seeing an Orthopedic doc for an injury to my shoulder he said he was going to prescribe me some Vicodin.  I had no idea what it was and jokingly asked him if I could get an RX for 1000 pills since I had a lot of pain.  He looked at me in anger and said "I will NOT give you 1000 pills!  All you can have is 100!"  And he gave me the RX for 100!  I had them filled and tried to take just 1/2 tab and almost passed out so the only way I could take any was by cutting them in quarters and taking a quarter of the pill with one tylenol.  I decided I was better off with the tylenols and ended up not taking the rest of the pills.  I just noticed recently I still had all the Vicodins in my drawer and knew they must be expired since it was about 10 years ago. (I like to save things!)  I finally trashed all of them.  My daughter said that would have been like gold to many other people and she could not believe I could not take them.  Frankly, I guess I am lucky my body is extra sensitive to drugs other than tylenols.  But I am glad they have them for those that can take them and need them.
Posts.Title: What pain meds to u use? Chelee Mazy1959

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2011 02:27PM - edited Aug 17, 2011 02:28PM by Medigal I think there is a misunderstanding with some of us as to what being a "survivor" means.  I was surprised recently to find out that it seems to have a different meaning to my oncologist and maybe many others.  From what I was told, they go by the type of cancer one gets and the diagnosis.  Some diagnosis have the "5 year" Survivor code on them and that seems to mean to the Onc that one has to be still alive or not have it return within 5 years to be able to consider onesself a "Survivor".  Others, with my diagnosis which seems to be more agressive, have a 15 year code and we must be alive and without bc for 15 years before we can consider ourselves as having survived it or call ourselves "survivors".  This is the reason that although I was diagnosed in 2003, he feels I still have 7 years to go before I can  be at peace that it won't return.  This is also the reason he insists I have to continue on the Arimidex for extra protection. However, as I wrote earlier, it is up to how one wants to interpret being a survivor and if your Onc follows the same theory as my Onc does.  So.....I guess I am still not a survivor until I can be at peace that it may never return again.
Posts.Title: How many years have you been a Survivor? IllinoisNancy Lou789

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2010 09:38AM Medigal wrote: Irina:  You need to call your Medicaid social worker.  You should keep her name and phone number handy since she should be assigned to you.  The social worker in hospital is not the same as the one Medicaid should have assigned to you.  If you don't have her name, call Medicaid and give them your information (Medicaid number etc.) and ask to speak to the social worker who is assigned to you.  If there is any  thing the Medicaid worker needs from you she should tell you and you can do what is necessary.  "Keep" your workers name and phone number always handy now that you are on Medicaid.  This is important.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 12:07AM Medigal wrote: I think people like Applegate should NOT be allowed to publicly say such negative remarks against a procedure like radiation.  There are those who, IMO, would change their mines about it if they think she considers it harmful to the body.  Also, she did not loose her breasts to bc, IMO, it was a choice she made to have the double mastec.  If she had opted for Chemo and Radiation she may have been able to keep her breasts.  No one knows the real answers as to how to really survive this horrible disease.  We all make our own choices and then have to live with the consequences.  I just think her statement may endanger some women who were already on the fence about Rads and now will refuse if they heard her.   I cannot understand what the fear is about radiation treatments.  I had 35 and did not have one side effect from them.  They do not make one nauseaus like Chemo can so what is the furor about Rads??  Celebrities DO influence many people so she should have known better than to be negative about these treatments where millions could hear her opinions.  "I did not choose to have radiation" would have been the best thing for her to have said and not add the negative part.

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2011 08:07PM Medigal wrote: We usually have to use the In Network Mail Pharmacy with our Medicare Advantage Plan but I found as long as I wasn't in the Medicare Donut "Mud" Hole (I call it) I could you a number of local pharmacies for my 90 day RXs for the same copay as their Mail Pharmacy.  I just have to make sure the RX is written for a 90 day supply with 3 refills and I just take it to the local pharmacy which has the cheapest cash price.  This way it can be a bit longer before I end up in the Donut Hole and have to pay cash for everything.  It's nice to have a choice.
Posts.Title: Does anybody get meds through mail? cookie97 nancyh

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2010 03:05PM Medigal wrote: meme31:  As long as your doctor lets your insurance "he" feels you need the biopsy due to a "suspicious" lump, it should be covered.  If for some reason you have an uncooperative doc, I would let them know emotionally I feel I need the biopsy to clear any doubts and see if you can work out a price with them for the procedure.  You would have to do the same with the hospital.  In the past I have gotten really big discounts for procedures for even the percent I owed which insurance didn't cover by agreeing to pay the entire amount at one time.  If you can't do that, just be honest with the rep at the hospital and I am sure she will give you a better price and work out some way for you to pay them.  If my insurance doesn't or won't cover something, I always insist (very nicely) that they give me the insurance's "contracted" price which is always much lower than the regular price.  Best of luck to you!

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2012 04:21PM Medigal wrote: Sheila:  I have the LE Bracelet on my right arm and a necklace around my throat.  I have a metal clip in my head from a cerebral aneurysm I had a year before bc diagnose and worse that the LE is what could happen to me if they ignored the necklace with the 'NO MRI" on it!  No doctors, nurses or any one in the medical profession dares touch my right arm.  Once when I had to go to a test to a local hospital I brought a sign with BIG Letters on it directing "NO ONE to touch my right arm for ANY TEST ETC? "  I told them I was prepared to SUE the hospital if they disobeyed.  I feel part of the training of any medical professional should be to especially look for these Medic Alert bracelets or other items we wear to protect ourselves. We have enough to worry about without having to do their work.   Just do whatever you have to do to make them aware.  Notes on the body, bed, walls etc. and this should be including the Medic Alert jewelry.  Best of luck to you!

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2010 05:26PM Medigal wrote: Ladies, I would like to run something by you on this subject of Vaginal Atrophy caused by Arimidex or the other ALs.  I had posted earlier that I am on a daily dose of Nitrofurantoin 50 mg. to stop the horrible excruciating pain I was having in that area and it had nothing to do with sex.  (I am long past those days!)  But since I am on my 6th year of Arimidex I have suddenly become very concerned about what may be going on in the deterioration of my personal parts that I can't see.  I don't want to wake up one day and find out my vagina is gone!  So last night I was wondering what if anything can be done to stop the deterioration if I continue to take the Arimidex.  At midnight last night I got up and ran into my bathroom and found that box of Replens my Onc suggested last year which I bought but only used 2 because I hate those icky things we put in us which leak out at times.  However, I decided to read for the first time the paper which came with it.  It said Replens not only replaces needed moisture we loose in that area but it helps sloge off the dead cells and gets new cells to form to protect the area from tears and bleeding.  THAT sounds like just what I need!  So I am going to start using it regularly (every 3 days it says) and hope that I can save what is left of my female parts just for posterity.  It frightens me to think that avoiding estrogen for so many years can deteriorate parts of my body that may cause me a lot of other problems in the future.  However, my Onc is a male and I don't think he gives my "v" much concern.  He just wants to keep me alive.  Maybe with Replens I can do both!  Have any of you used Replens on a regular basis and found it protected your private parts in the way I have described?  Thanks for any info.

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 07:58PM Medigal wrote: I would like to know if all of you who are registering and signing that Care2 Petition have bothered to read the "Terms of Service".  I was all set to sign when I got to #2 Description of Service and the part about Care 2 being allowed to send us service announcements and other commercial messages (as I understand it) and we will NOT be able to OPT OUT of receiving them.  I never have anything to do with any site which does not give me the right to "unsubscribe or opt-out" if I get tired of receiving unwanted emails from them or entities they are connected with.  This is the main reason I read the info about Dr. Tuohy's research and composed by own personal letters to people in Washington I felt might be of help or who could give me some idea of who would be the right people to contact.  I am most definitely for any and ALL research which might help protect my children and/or grandchildren even if it can't be done in time to help me.  However, I am very leary about signing my name or giving my email address on any websight I know little about.  I have spent too much time, in the short time I have owned my computer, "unsubscribing and opting out" of websites which once they got my email address flooded me with commercial information to buy stuff.  Sorry if it has made me a bit paranoid but we all must do things in the way which suits us best.  The fact that you don't have to sign your name was the trigger for me.  It's really always our "email addresses" they want and need, in my opinion.

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2012 12:22PM Medigal wrote: I will NEVER allow them to put me through that procedure again!  I have a spinal fusion and cannot lie on my stomach expect for a few minutes.  They caused me such pain and NO one was by by side to reassure me of anything!  Just two women doing weird stuff to my breast under the table.  No one told me to take a Xanax or anything!  That is why these forums are needed.  You at least can have an idea of what you are getting in to.  Next time they need a biopsy they need to sedate me completely and do it the "old fashion way"!  I still get panic attacks just thinking about what those heartless idiots put me through and I won't even go into when they both left me alone in the room clamped to the vise and terrifying me about what would happen to my breast if I moved!  If you have it done, make sure you get them to explain "everything" to you from minute to minute and ask for whatever meds you can get to make it easier on yourself.  Like I said, I don't feel what happened to me was the norm.   I trusted my doctor but after that, no more!

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2010 12:44PM Medigal wrote: I never heard of any doctor finding a lump in a woman's breast and not insisting on doing some kind of biopsy on it.  My daughter's mammo was negative but she found the lump herself and showed it to her gyn.  He then did a biopsy to find out what it was.  Thank God, it was benign but this is something they need to find out.  I had to have so many biopsies on both my breasts for years before the bc showed up because I had dense breasts.  However, they never ignored "any" lump.  I also have never heard of a doctor knowing a lump is benign just by how it looks on a mammo.  My Onc was told me that benign lumps do have a type of different look than cancerous ones but he just did not believe in risking my life on a "I think it is".  We are not playing with sore toes here.  This can be serious stuff if your docs "guess" wrong.  You are probably fine but I would insist they either do an ultrasound or a biopsy to find out what it is.  Best of luck

Here! For Female Gyns!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 03:57AM Medigal wrote: I was researching info on Dr. Vincent Tuohy and it mentioned getting funding from Komen for the Cure.  Do we know how many organizations he has already sent his request for funding to and if he has been granted any funds yet?  There are many organizations which researchers use to request funds for certain types of work and it would be helpful to know which ones, if any, have funded him or the Cleveland Clinic for this unique cancer research.  The Petitions I saw were for the US Congress and if they deny him, it would be helpful to know which other organizations he has not sent his request in to so we will not be wasting time requesting funds from those which may have already denied his request.  It seems the Cleveland Clinic would have a list of places their researchers would use to request funds.  Just wondering other than Komen for the Cure, which ones are they? Dr. Tuohy has already been interviewed about this research by USA Today, Webmd.com, and several other important news affiliates, including BBC from what I have read.  This is the reason I wonder if he has already been given certain funds for this research.  He and his cancer research is not as unknown as I first thought.  I do hope this works out for him so we can have more hope for a better future when it comes to cancer.

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 07:14PM Medigal wrote: Nela:  I think if you had "any" positive nodes they would be hitting you with the Chemo.  I had a diagnosis similar to yours with one positive node and I had to do the whole show:  Chemo, Rads, Lumpectomy and now Arimidex.  I would not risk my life on the fact that the mastectomy is the Ace card.  I agree with Claire that you should get a second opinion to make sure you are fighting this bc with everything necessary to your survival.  I have read that some Oncs skip the Chemo if one has the Mastectomy and no positive nodes but there seems to be disagreement on this issue.  So it is best to get that second opinion, IMO.  Best of luck with whatever you decide to do.

Arimidex for another 8 years as long as my bones don't deteriorate on me.  He doesn't seem to be concerned about what it is doing to me emotionally.  So even if I make it to the 15 year mark and am still surviving, it will have been a horrible 15 years!

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2010 11:08AM Medigal wrote: People there are many days I start to come on this forum and just can't.  I know the Memorial page someone put up was done for a good reason but when I scroll through all the names it just tears me up and I refuse to let my name be a part of it.  Our futures are already done in another place so it does us no good to live what days or years we are given in fear.  Whenever one of our own passes it is like it just reminds us no matter what we try to do, how long we survive is not really in our hands. Because of my overly emotional nature, I am the perfect example of someone doing everything wrong.  Except that I am so deligent on trying to survive, I take that Arimidex no matter how it makes me feel and I do everything my Onc thinks I need to do to survive.  Other than that, we have to busy ourselves on taking care of our loved ones and not concentrate any more than we have to on what is wrong with us.  This forum was meant to be a support group but in a way it makes us focus too much on bc.  That is not good for us.  As for prayer, I am devoted to it and feel the positive energy it fills me with can only help me not harm me.  Try to cheer up ladies.  If you are reading this, you have been given another day to survive!  My best wishes for all of us!

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2010 08:38AM Medigal wrote: Irina:  I am so sorry you are still having so many medical problems.  If you are already approved for Medicaid, you would have to find the type of nursing home which accepts patients with your medical problems and has the staff to help you.  Not all nursing homes are the same.  If you have a patient advocate or a social worker you are working with, they would be the best one to find the type of nursing home for your needs.  They would also decide whether it would be for a temporary or permanent basis after getting the necessary information from your doctor.  Unless one is wealthy, (which it seems clear you are not) one does not just walk up to any nursing home and ask for a room.  The social worker would have to find one with a Medicaid bed available for your needs.  Most nursing homes only have to have a certain number of Medicaid beds available so they go fast!  Unless the rules have changed recently, this is the way it was when I was researching them for a relative.  It sounds to me from your posts you are not going to get the treatment you need unless you get help soon.  You should have been assigned a social worker when you got into the Medicaid system so I would call her as soon as possible and let her get the ball rolling for the doctor, paperwork, and search for which homes in your area have a Medicaid bed available.  They should have a list of them.  This would be too difficult, for you to try to do alone and in order to get in the home you would still have to go through the social worker since all your finances have to be checked. It's not as easy as you may think so if this is what you feel you need, in my opinion, I would call the social worker first thing tomorrow (Monday).  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: No Tx for me Irina dlb823

We have to know who is the "head honcho" to get to and convince them "our cause" needs their funds more than "the how turtles mate cause" if you know what I mean.

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 02:55PM Medigal wrote: Irina:  I agree with you that from what I have researched Dr. Tuohy "is" well known world-wide whether he realizes it or not.  What I don't understand is why isn't he flooded with grants to continue such promising research.  So it works on rats!  Rats are what they have to use "first"!  I was just recently told that billionaires like Bill Gates and others are building "Bill and Milenda Gates Charity Organization" and trying to get billionaires to give 50% supposedly of their income to charities.  If this is true then how much better for them to use some of that money to "try" for a cure for cancer! In my opinion, in the financial state our nation is in now, the US Congress is not in any shape to give much research funds and the petitions would best go to places where Dr. Tuohy stands a better chance of actually "getting" the money.  I spent a lot of my life getting money for research for another chronic disease and you would not believe where the biggest donations come from!  It was NOT the US government!   Just my two cents worth.

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2010 01:28PM Medigal wrote: Irina:  Palliative care???  Maybe you should ask them the same question you just posted here.  Maybe you wouldn't need "palliative care" now if somebody had found a place for you to go where they could give you the treatments and care you need so much.  I think the stress of your trying to get your treatments has weakened your condition.  Your social worker needs to do less talking and more getting you the help you need, IMO.  Do hope you find a way to hang on before they end up having to do "palliative care".  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: No Tx for me Irina dlb823

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2010 05:44PM Medigal wrote: Irina, I can't believe that social worker gives "you" a website to search for a nursing home!  I went through this for a relative and it is NOT that easy!  She was supposed to find a home which has a Medicaid bed available, is qualified to handle your medical problems and then if she finds more than one, she can allow you to select the one you prefer.  In my opinion, as sick as you are, you are not strong enough to do the hunts for the nursing home.  Is your daughter well enough and knows our language enough to talk to that social worker for you?   Are you supposed to make all those phone calls to each home and ask them if they have a Medicaid bed available and can handle your specific medical problems??  I am appalled that social worker is putting this off on you.  Some people want to do this on their own but they are not as sick as you.  Explain this to her!  You will need help in doing this.  I know the language and I assure you, it was a job for me to find just the "right" place my relative needed.  Medicaid beds are not always available in every home you may find.  You or someone has to contact them to find out first.  Best of luck to you Irina.  I do hope you find a relative or friend to help you with this.
Posts.Title: No Tx for me Irina dlb823

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2010 11:28AM - edited Sep 5, 2010 11:30AM by Medigal Susan, I applaud you for your chuapaz (can't spell it) for being able to voice your opinions of what I posted to Irina.  You are right that she can post whatever she wants here but then again, we have to be ready for the reactions of others to our posts.  I am not angry at your chewing me off because of my reply to her so why should Irina be angry because I am confused about what she posts and would like to have some answers "if SHE chooses to reply".  I did not say she would be shot before dawn or thrown off the forum if she doesn't decide to reply.  In fact, I don't  expect a reply or answer from her.    Please reread my reply to her.  I was very loving, compassionate and kind to her.  I did not say anything cruel to her because I know she is Stage IV and we all are very concerned about her. I think my questions were of a concern to get to the bottom of why she isn't being helped so that she could get the help she needs. What selfish motive could I have for wanting Irina to be helped?? Your question and post confuses me.  How much help have you offered to Irina?  If you have it would never occur to me that it would be from selfish motives.  BTW, I resent your insinuating I was telling Irina she couldn't vent, spew, whine, complain etc. on this forum.  You seem to be misreading everything I posted.  My request to Irina for answers was only to see if we could get to the bottom of her denials so she could get the help she says she needs.  Sorry you read into my post such cruel statements.  They are only in your head.  Not in my post to Irina.   Welcome to our group!  It is so nice we can be so honest with one another.  But bc does that to one.  It makes us real honest!

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2010 07:34PM Medigal wrote: Irina, I can't imagine having to cope with cancer alone.  I am the Queen of crying and I am not alone! I truly believe God gave us tears to flush out all the fears and hurt inside of us.  So don't be afraid to cry or think it means you are weak.  You are just human.  I think we all have said the "Why Me?"  but we don't get to know why in "this" life.  I do hope you have the help you need all lined up and can feel better so you can do your treatments and keep this damnable disease from winning!  Best of luck to you!

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2010 07:55PM Medigal wrote: Irina:  Make this easy on yourself.  Call the Medicaid office and ask to speak to the Medicaid Social Worker who is assigned to "you".  Write down her name and any special phone number she has. Then make sure "she" knows about your medical problems and why you need a nursing home.  Unless they have changed things recently, the Medicaid social worker assigned to "your case" is supposed to help you find that nursing home not the social worker at the hospital.  I think you are getting confused because they are both called "social workers".   Even if you were able to pick a nursing home from that list the other one gave you, you will still have to go through "your" Medicaid social worker. I am not on Medicaid but I know how it has always worked for people I tried to help. This will take a lot of stress off of you and "you" will still be able to make the decision if you want the nursing home the Medicaid worker offers to you. Like Deanna wrote, if you want one closer to your daughter or oncologist, tell her this when you speak to her.  As I have said repeatedly, the nursing homes only have to allow a small number of beds for Medicaid patients so one has to be found that has a Medicaid bed available in the area you prefer. Let us know how you make out but call the Medicaid office as soon as you can.

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 04:23PM Medigal wrote: I am a great believer that stress plays an important part in triggering off bc.  However, I feel you have to have other triggers.  With me, I just know it was all the hormones I took during menopause and now I am ER+PR+ etc.  But somehow I think my system was broken down by other medical and personal problems in my life that caused intense stress.  So yes, I do believe stress is one of the main triggers of bc.  Can I prove it?  No.  But a lot of stuff that happens to us can't be proven even by the medical profession.  Your post sounds like you haven't exactly conquered the additional stress (GRRRR!!!)

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2010 05:31PM Medigal wrote: Poor Irina!!  That social worker is going to have a great time actually putting the selection of the nursing home on Irina!!  Irina does not know the difference between the types of homes!  I went through this crap for a relative and there is a lot to understand.  Irina will be back in the hospital by the time she tries to figure out which nursing home she needs.  That social worker has access to finding out which homes have a Medicaid bed left and if they are the type to take people with Irina's medical problems.  This is very sad that she is putting this off on Irina.  She should select a few qualified ones and allow Irina to pick the one she feels is closer to the area she wants.  I think someone needs to send an advocate to Irina to help her with this before she gets sicker from all this stress!!  Does anyone on here live near her??  That poor lady is like a fish trying to swim in a frozen ocean.  Where is her daughter?  She should be able to explain things to her mom about how the nursing home system works.  What a mess!!
Posts.Title: Has any heard from Irina dmacw Medigal

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2010 07:15PM - edited Aug 15, 2010 07:17PM by Medigal There is surgery and then there is "surgery"!  My surgeon refused to take mine even tho I gave him permission to to make sure to save my life.  When I awoke and "most" of it was still there I was shocked and his answer was "I took everything I felt I needed to take and left everything I didn't need to take".  He then set me up for Chemo and rads to follow.  Arimidex did not start until the rest was done.  So I guess some surgeons are not as aggressive as others and I just have to "hope" he knew what he was doing!   I  was once informed by a person who did a lot of studying in this area that having total masectomies don't always prove more protective than what my surgeon did.  It seems more surgeons are trying to save more of the breasts and adding the chemo and rads.  However, when they have a patient who is terrified of chemo and rads then they may not have any other choice to "slice and dice" as you so aptly put it.
Posts.Title: Why not just keep the breast? Halah dlb823

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2010 11:49PM Medigal wrote: Dave: I am so glad to hear they got Kimberly's bp down.  But PLEASE make sure they do the MRI. I had a similar problem years ago with practically all the symptoms Kimberly has.  The cat scan did not pick up the problem and I was sent home and ended up having a cerebral aneurysm.  The MRI found the aneurysm and they were able to save my life.  I am so relieved you have Kimberly where they can watch her and do whatever tests she needs.  Just don't let them discharge her until they do that MRI and find out what caused the edema.  In my experience, doctors are only as good as we "make" them be.  You and Kimberly will be in my prayers tonight.  She is very fortunate you got her to the Trauma Center in time.
Posts.Title: Today was frightening day Kimberly is in ICU dhmeiser RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2010 12:20PM Medigal wrote: Dave:  I am so sorry for what has happened to Kimberly but so grateful she is in the hands of people who can find out what has gotten her to this state.  Blood Pressure that high has to be caused by something.  I am just so glad they ruled out the cerebral aneurysm!  Even doctors don't always take "headaches" in women seriously.  I was "almost" a casualty of my doctor thinking it was nerves and I ended up having the aneurysm!  Make sure they check out every possibility for what is causing this.  You and Kimberly will be in my prayers.  I pray she has a complete recovery and they find soon what is causing this.
